results.title: Peter Principle: jumping for jelly beans, etc.
results.brief_description: Peter Principle. Dr. Peter offers his disturbing insight into why people get promoted to their level of competence. Why people struggle up the hierarchy of an organization when it is no good for neither them or the company? “Jumping Jelly Beans” Professor Fred Hezberges name is associated with the study of motivation. Here he delivers his theories in a stimulating lecture. “Up the organization”. Robert Townsend expounds his radical philosophy on the subject of running a business. No department is safe from his challenging and witty criticism.

results.title: Peter and the wolf (K)
results.creator_credit: Clyde Geronimi and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Disney’s animated version of “Peter and the Wolf” follows several years after his classic film “Fantasia”. Disney continues his use of music and detailed animation with music from Sergei Prokofiev matched to the characters of the story. Each character is introduced at the beginning of the tale with their appropriate musical instrument from the orchestra. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Peter's chair
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Using Ezra Jack Keats book as a basis, this film tells of the jealousy Peter feels at the arrival of his baby sister and how his world is put to rights again. Good use of music and amusing and entertaining voice-overs.

results.title: Pesticides
results.creator_credit: Robert Richter, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Pesticides and pills for export only”.
The film presents evidence that products banned or restricted in developed countries because of their danger to humans or the environment are knowingly exported to the Third World by multinational corporations. This episode investigates the trade in pesticides.

results.title: Peruvian plateau
results.brief_description: How primitive methods of mining and transportation have been replaced by modern methods which have helped to increase the wealth obtained from the Andean peaks and plateau of Peru.

results.title: Peru: the revolution that never was
results.creator_credit: Peter Tiffin, David Elstein and Thames Television
results.brief_description: Shows the abject poverty and miserable life style still endured by Peruvian peasant farmers, and notes how the changes to the land tenure system brought about by the 1968 revolution have failed to bring any change in the deplorable living standards of the Peruvian peasant farmer. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: Peru people of the Andes
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explores the Chincheros Valley near Cuzco and contrasts the community life in a self contained Indian Village with that of the tenant farmers who work on the haciendas. Illustrates Peru’s recent economic progress as evidenced in the new mining camps, transportation facilities and the wealth which is concentrated in Lima. (Revision of 1940 film, “Peru”.)
